dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air is thick with dust. Grain is being milled, a loud steady GRINDING: WE SEE the machinery moving in the shift light. Shelves line one wall, sagging with burlap sacks. MITCHELL is tallying the bags on a Clipboard. He's thirty old, slim, light~haired, dressed in khakis and a sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall narrow building, roofed with corrugated tin. It's separated from the feedstore by a barren, snow-covered ya The snow is dirty, pockmarked with tracks. We still HEAR grinding, but it's more muffled now. The mill's door opens, and Hank emerges, clutching his Glipboard. He coughs, spits into the snow, then picks his quickly toward the feedstore, slapping at his sweater and as he goes, leaving a cloud of dust in the air behind hin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny office, which Hank shares with his boss, TOM BUTLE bookshelves are crowded with files; the desks are messy; fluorescent light flickers on the ceiling. Butler, a heav man approaching forty, is talking on the phone: no words, an intermittent string of HMMM‘'s, UH-HUH's, and UNE-UNH' Hank enters, plucks the top sheet of paper from his clipb deposits it on Butler's desk. Butler scans its columns wi pausing in his conversation. As Hank sits down at his own slightly smaller desk, his watch BEEPS. He fumbles with i checking the time: it's noon. Hank hurriedly shuts his briefcase, turns off his desk la When he steps to the door and pulls down his coat, Butler glances at his own watch, raising his eyebrows, the phone pressed to his ear. Hank hesitates, halfway into his over

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: The cemetery..? (Butler's face remains blank) My brother and I... Butler nods, suddenly remembering, and waves Hank away. H rushes out the door. It SLAMS shut, then immediately pops open as Hank sticks his head in. HANK (cont'd) Happy New Year!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Butler can respond, the door shuts, and Hank is go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, worn-looking town. The street is lined with two- buildings, their paint peeling, gutters sagging. The few out and about are dressed heavily against the cold. Snow been shoveled into long piles along the sidewalk's edge. tattered Christmas decorations cling to the light poles. Hank emerges from the feedstore, buttoning his overcoat. turns to the right, hurrying, his head ducked against the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Hank down the block. He passes a woman carrying bulging grocery bag, a SMALL CHILD trailing behind her, androgynous in its snow gear. The woman's name is LINDA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, Lindal (to the child) Happy New Year, Marcil The mother and daughter both RESPOND, their faces too muf their scarves for us to make out their words. HANK walks on, passing a tavern, several stores, the libr all of the buildings look equally rundown. Only the town stands out in any way, a red-brick structure with a polic parked on the street before it. CARL JENKINS, the town policeman, a white-haired, vigorous-looking old man, is s the truck's windshield. He waves at Hank.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, Hank! As Hank waves back, a little girl glides toward him down sidewalk, perched on a sled: silent, almost magical. Hank steps aside to let her pass. Then he turns the corner, st down the next block. He stops at--

dialogues.speaker: THE MITCHELL HOUSE
dialogues.text: --which is just a bit less dilapidated than its neighbors essentially rundown building with a thin facade of renova fresh paint, clean windows, a wreath on the door. Christm lights blink on the porch railings. Hank climbs the steps vanishes inside, the door SLAMMING shut behind him.

dialogues.speaker: END CREDITS
dialogues.text: INT. MITCHELL ENTRANCEWAY —- DAY Hank pauses inside the door, unbuttoning his coat. To his is the dining room, to his left the living room. Nothing' expensive, but all the furnishings have obviously been ch with care. A poinsettia sits on a table by the front door Hank drapes his coat over the bannister, bends to remove shoes, then stops, listening. WE HEAR water running, and- faintly to make out the words--a woman singing. Hank yank his shoes, starts quickly up the stairs. INT. MITCHELL BEDROOM —- DAY A bed, night tables, a pair of bureaus. Photographs dot t walls; the windows look out onto the street. A door, crac open, leads to a bathroom. This is where the water's comi from: Hank's wife, SARAH, is singing in the shower. We ca HEAR her words now. She's singing, "In the Bleak Midwinte Hank enters, moves to the bathroom door. Very slowly, he it open, steps into--

Hank stan the center of the room, perfectly silent, listening. After a few beats, the singing stops and the water is tur off. Then the shower curtain is slowly pulled open, revea

She flinches the sight of Hank, startled, hiding behind the shower cur It clings to her body, betraying the huge dome of her bel she's extremely pregnant. After a moment, she smiles, and grabs a towel, steps forward with it, holding it out to h Neither of them says a word.

WE RISE into the air, watching the fox set off into the f its paws throwing up a wake of snow. On the horizon, WE S dark mass of trees. The fox is heading straight for them.

Jacob glances fr to Lou, bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB

dialogues.speaker: JACOB

W he doesn't take it, Lou tosses it at him. It smacks Hank chest; he catches it as it bounces off. LOU (cont ‘d) Why give it up before we even know if someone's looking for it? ON HANK, as he stares down at the money, hefting it in hi The other men watch him, waiting. Hank opens his mouth to speak, but then stops, hesitating, trying to make his way through this new territory, struggling to discern a path. Finally, slowly, as if he were merely thinking out loud:

dialogues.text: All of it?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Sust till spring. Till someone finds the plane. Lou And then?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: That's the only way I'll do it. Otherwise, we can turn it in right now. Jacob gives his brother a quizzical look.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB
dialogues.text: You don't trust us? Hank hesitates, weighing the merits of a truthful answer.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I guess I don't. Jacob nods. He doesn’t seem surprised. Hank turns to Lou.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HANK (cont‘d) No promises. If it looks like anyone's searching for the money, I'll burn it, and that'll be that. Jacob and Lou stare at each other, silently debating. Fin Jacob shrugs, tossing his packet back into the bag. Lou (threatening) We count it first. Hank and Lou lock eyes for a moment. Then Hank nods.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: That's probably a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Well congratulations, Sarah. I guess you know more than the FBI. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: But if he's really from the FBI, it'll look suspicious if I don't help. As he watches Sarah search for a response, WE HEAR the st timer go off. It goes on and on, but neither of them reac

(a bewildered look from Sarah) The snow'll cover my tracks. By the time--

dialogues.text: Hank-- Hank stands up abruptly, nearly knocking over his chair. heads toward the hall, leaving his food untouched behind

Waiting for Tom Butler to retire or die so you can finally get a raise? 97. 124 She stops at the foot of the stairs. Hank has vanished up but she keeps SHOUTING after him. SARAH (cont'd) , Coming home each evening to this cheap, ugly house, with the basement flooding every spring, the furnace breaking down twice a year, those disgusting yellow tiles on the kitchen floor? Is that all it'll take to make you happy? Bank reappears at the top of the stairs. He starts down t dragging the duffel bag behind him. SARAH (cont'd) What about Amanda? You think she's gonna like growing up in somebody else's hand-me- down clothes? Playing with other kid's old toys because we can never afford to buy her anything new? Hank reaches the bottom of the stairs, turns to Sarah, a look on his face,

Hank examines Carl's body, making sure Jac hasn't disturbed it. Then he turns back toward Jacob. HANK (cont'd) You understand what we're gonna say? Jacob doesn't respond. Hank steps toward him. HANK (cont’d) It's simple. {he holds up his pistol) We're gonna tell them Carl loaned me the pistol to signal if I found the plane, and when I saw Baxter shoot him, I-~ Jacob lifts his head. His face is wet with tears. He rise his feet, his rifle slipping off his shoulder into the sn gives Hank a desolate look. -

dialogues.speaker: JACOB
dialogues.text: We can't, Hank. (CONTINUED)

Hank shakes his arm, shouts HANK (cont'd) Do you? (seemingly against his will, Jacob nods) Well this is how you get it. Right here. Right now. He starts to drag Jacob from the plane, past Carl's body. heat of Carl’s blood has begun to melt the surrounding sn HANK (cont’d) This is what it costs-- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: After a few feet, Jacob pulls his arm away. He turns to H suddenly intense, points toward Baxter.

dialogues.text: Use his gun. Hank gives him a stupefied look. Jacob shuffles to Baxter body, picks up the dead man's pistol, holds it out to Han Hank hesitates, then takes it. Jacob nods his approval. JACOB (cont'd) I don't wanna go to jail, Hank. Hank seems relieved by these words.

dialogues.text: You don't have to. We're gonna-- Jacob shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB
dialogues.text: I can't pretend like you... (a pause) Do it in the head, okay? / Hank stands frozen: confused, frightened, the guns in his hands. Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB

dialogues.speaker: JACOB
dialogues.text: Here. He steps forward, reaching to take back the gun. Hank ret scared. Jacob shuffles to Carl's corpse, crouches, remove policeman's gun from its holster. Then he stands, faces H

dialogues.text: You have to... (he points toward Baxter's pistol) It won't make sense if I--~ His dog rubs against his legs, distracting him. He stares at her for a beat, then stoops to pet her. He hugs her ro kisses the top of her head.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Jacob. Jacob pushes the dog away, rises, lifts Carl's pistol. Fo instant it looks as if he's going to aim it at Hank, but presses it to his own temple. HANK (cont'd) (horrified) Jacob!

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: as two men, dressed in identical overcoats, approach him behind. They're Special Agents RENKINS and FREMONT. Fremo has the plastic bag full of money.

dialogues.text: FREMONT (cont'd) been properly trained, there are many ways to detect a liar. There's a dark red gash across Hank's cheek, but the woun stopped bleeding. He gives Fremont a frightened look.

dialogues.text: I don't--

dialogues.speaker: FREMONT
dialogues.text: The shifty eyes of pulp fiction have a certain basis in fact. A wooden or stilted tone, gestures that seem either slightly robotic or unnecessarily expansive-- Renkins nods in agreement, joining in.

dialogues.speaker: RENKINS
dialogues.text: Details tend to be vague, slippery. Sometimes the suspect will cover his mouth with his hand as he speaks... Fremont rests his palms on the desk, leans toward Hank. FREMONT a You notice anything like that from the man you shot today? Hank still hasn't grasped what the agent is saying. He gl from Renkins to Fremont, gives a nervous shake of his hea FREMONT (cont'd) He was lying to you, Mr. Mitchell. He wasn't from the FBI. Hank lifts his hand, starts to cover his mouth, but then realizes what he's doing and quickly lowers it. He strugg mask his relief, to feign confusion.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I don't understand. He said-- Fremont nods; he knows what he said.

dialogues.speaker: FREMONT
dialogues.text: His name was Vernon Bokovsky. His brother was in that crashed plane you found out there today.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: He was looking for his brother? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The words seem to suck everything out of Hank; for an ins he looks as if he might crumple. The other two men don't to notice. Renkins leans forward, opens the bag of money.

dialogues.speaker: RENKINS
dialogues.text: He was looking for this. He shakes it, displaying the money. Hank stares, unseeing

dialogues.speaker: FREMONT
dialogues.text: Bokovsky and his brother were the guys who kidnapped that McMartin girl last November. You remember? The one they shot and dumped in the lake?

dialogues.speaker: RENKINS
dialogues.text: Four point four million dollars in ransom. Hank continues to stare into the bag, completely absent; hasn't heard a word they've said. The agents smile at eac other, misinterpreting his reaction. Renkins reaches into bag, pulls out a packet, holds it out to Hank. RENKINS (cont'd) Wanna touch it? Hank blinks up at him, too dazed to answer. Renkins nods encouragingly. RENKINS (cont'd) Go ahead, Hank finally realizes what the man wants of him. He takes packet, balances it for a moment in his palm, then hands to Renkins, who returns it to the bag. RENKINS (cont'd) This is only part of it, of course. we're still tracking down the rest.

dialogues.speaker: FREMONT
dialogues.text: (confidently) Just a question of time. The words jerk Hank back into the conversation. He glance apprehensively from Renkins to Fremont.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: FREMONT
dialogues.text: We had the money for two hours before the kidnappers picked it up. We couldn’t mark (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FREMONT (cont'd) it--we were afraid they'd detect the markings and kill the girl--so we put together a task force of twenty agents, and they wrote down as many of the serial numbers as they could. We ended up recording just under five thousand of them, one out of ten of the bills. Hank stares at them, too shocked to speak.

dialogues.speaker: RENKINS
dialogues.text: Simply a matter of waiting for the numbers to turn up. You can’t go around passing hundred dollar bills without eventually sticking in someone’s memory.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (stunned) The money’s marked.

dialogues.speaker: FREMONT
dialogues.text: That’s what it amounts to. Marked money. Renkins leans back in his chair, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RENKINS
dialogues.text: Crime doesn't pay.
